ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Live lectures over zoom
The lectures were live and attendance was mandatory but they were recorded and posted on Canvas after the class.
The live virtual lectures were also recorded and posted on Canvas, which were useful for reviewing material and/or catching up whenever I was unable to attend the live session.
Sometimes instead of watching the lectures live I would watch the recordings asynchronously.
Weekly virtual discussion sections
Live section
Virtual lecture as well as a discussion section where we could ask questions and review the material from the lecture
Live virtual lecture with virtual section.
Live lecture and discussion section.
Recorded & live virtual lecture, as well as live section.
None
Love and recorded lecture plus live sections
There was a combination of recorded and live virtual lecture.
Live and recorded virtual lectures and sections
live section, recorded lecture, live virtual lecture

live lectures were recorded,
and one section a week
Mixture of live virtual lecture and recorded lecture, depending on how it fit into my personal schedule.
Live virtual discussion sections + live virtual lecture
Once a week section, online.
recorded live lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
basics of game theory with fascinating political science application
how to solve games and think about their real-world meaning
Game theory and how it applies to political science models.
I learned about game theory fundamentals, such as: identifying Nash equilibria, solving static vs. dynamic games, and working with incomplete vs. complete information.
I learned a lot of introductory game theory material within a political science-specific framework.
I learned how to find equilibria in games and think analytically about political situations using game theory frameworks. It was interesting!
all the game theory strategies and methods.
I gained a better understanding of the concepts a game theorist makes use of and became comfortable working with matrices, game trees, and finding the BNE and PBE.

In terms of the Game Theory portion of the course, I learned about different types of Nash equilibrium for different games. The mathematics were pretty easy (though I needed to be careful with my calculations to not make silly mistakes) in terms of arithmetic, though some problems were initially difficult to sort through logically. 

The Political Science aspect meant applying the different equilibria to political situations, especially bureaucratic processes. This material was only tested in a shallow way (exams were more game-heavy than political science-heavy). I think it would be interesting to a person interested in political science and bureaucracy, and a different way of thinking. 

Be sure to read the textbook as it is an important part of understanding the material! Our class got hit hard when an exam problem was on textbook stuff and we hadn't studied it..
Basics behind game theory and some theoretical applications to political science.
Game Theory (prisoner's dilemma, nash equilibrium, mixed strategies, bayesian nash equilibrium, perfect bayesians)

I took this class to fulfill the EP&E game theory requirement, and it was pretty interesting. We cover a lot of political applications to game theory, and they definitely make you think. Otherwise, the main skills are pretty quantitative.
Learned about game theory (different types of games) and some applications to domestic politics.

Game theory concepts like nash equilibrium and median voter theory up to perfect Bayesian equilibrium. No advanced math and very little political science. The toy examples occasionally are political topics but none of the content is inherently political science.
I learned various game theory concepts.
I now have a greater understanding of Game Theory!
I knew nothing about game theory before taking this course, and learned deeply about the concept and particularly its application in political science.
I learned about game theory and how to predict/analyze players' moves in different scenarios.
this is a good intro to solving games, but after the course, I am still not sure how I would apply this knowledge
critical thinking, problem solving, conceptualizing
Learned the fundamentals of game theory
Gained a basic understanding of game theory fundamentals but with some specific applications to political science.
A deeper understanding on how game theory may play a part in political science and society as a whole.
Very thought-provoking, motivated me to learn more about game theory.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strength: lecture with Turner is awesome, slides are really helpful, sections are clear, psets are efficient (no busywork but reinforce concepts), really interesting take-aways and applications
weakness: unclear how much we should know from textbook
This was a nice course, maybe doing actual problems during lectures would be helpful, but besides that was a good class. If Collin is TAing the class, sign up for his section, he is the best!!

Strengths: Professor Turner, who was able to teach the material in an interesting and engaging manner, and the TAs, who were very helpful with reviewing material and answering questions. Weaknesses: none.
I think the course is very well laid out. The flow from lecture to lecture was conducive to our learning. The psets prepared us well for the exams, and the exams were fair.
Very well taught and the material is really engaging. Wouldn't really have changed much

MOST IMPORTANT: Take it with Collin! He is a great TA. I highly recommend trying to get into his section because he is very clear and so helpful. Go to his office hours for help with PSETs. It is worth it!

Professor Turner is a big strength of the course. He is totally sweet and makes lots of dad jokes. Also I noticed he uses always female pronouns for the games which is cool. Lecture was pretty good, especially if you are interested in political science and its processes. Collin helped a lot with the PSETs, which definitely helped me learn. The TA review sessions and practice questions were good, though one problem on exam 2 didn't have a corresponding practice question and hence many students bombed it (read the textbook! It's important). Exams in general are pretty fair though.

Maybe a weakness is that the political science aspect isn't covered on the exams, which are pretty game-heavy. Otherwise I thought the course was strong, which is saying something considering I am not especially interested in politics.

Also, I would have liked for the PSETs to be scheduled ahead of time so I knew how to distribute my work. We always had enough time to do them, so it was no sweat, but I just would have liked the structure of it..
Fun course. Decided to credit d the class early on due to my semester's workload. Turned out to be a mistake. Fun class that you can do well in even just watching lectures.

Strengths: Superb course, fantastic instructor, straightforward psets, easy exams, amazing TA
No Weakness

Strengths are probably the depth and detail you go into with each problem, Professor Turner's passion for the subject, and the TAs of this course. Weaknesses are that sometimes it can feel like Professor Turner rushes over material to try and fit it in (frequently going over the 50 min).

This course was good.  It is definitely an introduction and was not too difficult which honestly made the students like and appreciate the material more.  The biggest weakness was that Ian ran over by like 8 minutes half the lectures which can be annoying.
Turner is a great lecturer and even better on double speed (thanks canvas media library). Section wasnt particularly helpful but did give opportunity to ask questions.
Strengths: Professor Turner is truly one of the best Professors at Yale because it is evident that he cares deeply about his students and the material he covers.

The course was fun and interesting. Some of the exams were strangely difficult or out of the blue, though. Like a lot of people got screwed over by 1 question we didn't really cover in class in the second exam and the final was the length of a pset (expected to be completed in 1 hour and 20 minutes).

Strength: Great TFs
Weakness: Exams dont always reflect problem sets
I liked how we went through a lot of example questions in class to learn how to apply the knowledge we were learning.
the instructor explained how to solve games clearly. I am still a little cloudy on the applications of the knowledge, however.

Loved the course content but I wish that we could have covered more content before the first unit exam and paced a bit slower for the next two exams, which I felt had concepts that were much harder to grasp.

Started an amazing course and felt very engaged although I felt towards the final third of the course it was rushed, as well as this being the hardest part.More time was needed to cover last few weeks and could easily be done by cutting down time spent on the first few weeks.

Strengths - Professor Turner and the TFs! They did a great job making sure we understood the concepts, especially since everything was virtual. The review sessions were helpful and we were given a good number of practice problems. 

Weaknesses - Not many really, but sometimes I was confused about what concepts we needed to focus on for exams.
The course is interesting but expected format of answers was often very specific so a very clear description of what is required in each answer would have been helpful.
TAs and discussion sections are very helpful.
Great introductory course, made game theory topics accessible to those of all majors. No real weaknesses.
I think it was just a bit more difficult given the online aspect considering its a Econ class, but the professor still did well with trying to keep us engaged.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: N/A

I liked that the lectures were still live even though it was over zoom, but sometimes they ran way too long and it was hard to focus at the end. The psets and tests were fair, and I appreciated all the practice assignments  we had leading up to the midterms.

Recording each live lecture was quite useful, since it allowed me to catch up and/or review material if needed. Virtual engagement was relatively low in lectures, so that could perhaps be improved upon, but engagement during discussion sections and office hours was fine.

I cannot think of ways to improve the course's Covid-adjusted practices. Professor Turner adapted his lectures to Zoom quite well. Even given the circumstances I cannot think of flaws in the course's proceedings.
Lectures went really well. Section was also fun.
At times, it was difficult to follow along during lecture, and I think having break out rooms where students tried problems or even going through more examples during class would be helpful.

I was pretty engaged in the course, even though it was virtual. Collin's section was great and he answered all our questions. Lecture was good, especially because we got the slides ahead of time and could follow along without writing frantically. I went to live lecture and stayed after for questions, which was definitely helpful..
Worked out very well!

PLEASE KEEP THE RECORDED LECTURES. They help with learning so much since they allow for students to rewind lectures and focus on learning the content instead of hastily scribbling down notes and missing stuff.

We were allowed to ask questions during the lecture, but I think there should be an allotted time for questions at the end. That would help increase engagement, and ensure that more students attend the lectures live.
This course did great in the pandemic.  Accommodating professor and TAs.
Nobody turned on cameras during lecture which was awkward.
I liked recorded lectures, as I could review them later at any time.
I thought lectures and sections were very engaging.
Couldn't have improved their approach to online learning.
Instead of optional sections, recorded videos on how to solve each of the various types of problems combined with an optional Q&A session might be a more efficient combination.
The live lecture (which is also recorded) is very helpful as I could go back and rewatch the lectures to solidify my knowledge.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 110%. Laid-back yet stimulating environment to learn about a theoretical mode of analysis with very practical applications.
Yes this is a great class with a great teaching team that was super understanding of the craziness of the semester which unfortunately has been rare among other yale classes in my experience.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! Professor Turner and the TAs are great, and the structure of the course (game theory being presented from a political science viewpoint) makes the content very interesting and applicable to real-life scenarios.

I'd recommend this to someone who needs to take game theory as a major requirement and/or is interested in pursuing political science as a career since the material we learned is necessary to master before learning higher-level political science-specific game theory content.

Yeah it was pretty good! Prof Turner is really engaging and the weekly discussion sections helped hammer in the concepts and clarify misconceptions. It didn't really have much political science content though. It was more like game theory tools occasionally applied to political situations, but I don't think I learned any political theory, which would've been interesting to see more of.
Yes, its a great course, super interesting and not a crazy amount of work. The right amount of work that keeps you motivated and engaged.

I took this course for a QR credit and because I liked the Game Theory unit of microeconomics. I also took it because it got good reviews and didn't sound too difficult.

The course is not necessarily a gut! There are 7 PSETs and three exams. None of them are particularly hard, especially if you got to office hours, but I studied quite a bit for the course. I could see my math major best friend taking this and thinking it was insanely easy, but I am not a math person so I had to work hard but ultimately it was possible to do well. 

I would recommend the course to a student who was interested in government and political science. Professor Turner talked a lot about how to apply the games to different political situations. Honestly as a humanities kid I just wasn't that engaged with these bits, but I could see them being TOTALLY fascinating for a political science/EPE/Global/history student who thinks about this stuff all the time. 

Overall I would tell a friend to take this course if they wanted a relatively low workload and unstressful class, a QR, and to learn a bit about American government. It wasn't life-changing like many Yale courses, but it was a solid course and I don't regret taking it..
Yes. Fun course!

Highly Recommend. DO NOT BOTHER READING OTHER COURSE EVALUATIONS, STOP RIGHT HERE! This course is a yale gem. Do yourself a favor and take the course! No further information is needed. And if you pick a TA, pick COLLIN!

As an EP&E requirement, yes. If you want to learn more game theory, ECON 159 would probably be a better choice, since they move at a quicker pace. If interested in specifically political science applications of game theory, then yes.
Yes if you are interested in the subject or are trying to fulfill a requirement.  Almost definitely better than the other game theory options.  It is interesting, if you like math it is fun.
Yes for major requirements (I took for cogsci breadth). Definitely way easier than the Econ game theory course so Im glad I took it. Covers pretty much the same topics I think.
Yes, not only is it a pretty easy QR but the material is also very engaging.
Sure, if you need it for your major or if you're genuinely interested.

I would recommend this course 100%. As a political science major that needed a quant, I was searching near and far for a quant that would be applicable and practical to my current studies and long term goals--Game theory checks both of the boxes. Professor Turner showed up to lectures twice a week excited to teach the class and it showed. The weekly PSETS allowed for me to further my understanding on Game Theory and kept me engaged. I am thankful that I was able to enroll in such a great course. I would take it again if I could!!
I would, but only if they have an interest in game theory AND political science.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning about game theory!
I would recommend this course. not insanely hard or too much work and reasonably interesting lectures.
Absolutely. The course content is fun and challenging, the professor is great and understanding, and the TFs feel a lot more personal than I've had in most of my other courses.
Yes a very good course. Content is easy to get your head around. Taught well.
Yes. This is a great intro to game theory that assumes no prior knowledge of concepts. I also really enjoyed the applications of the concepts to political science as we went along in the course

If you are interested in game theory and it fits better into your schedule than the economics one the other semester (if it still is taught that way) then check out this course, but expect there to be a couple lectures about specific political science topics that may or may not interest you.
Yes, if you are interested in game theory, economics and human behavior. The knowledge gained in this class is applicable to many different fields.
Yes, without a doubt.
yes, but more for Econ than political science.
